awd_titl_txt: 2022 GRC on Granular Matter: Particulate Systems Across Scales: From Colloidal Science to Geophysical Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides funding to partially support graduate students, post-docs, and under-represented and female early faculty to attend and present at the symposium on Quantum and Topological materials at the 2022 Granular Matter Gordon Research Conference (GRC) and Gordon Research Seminar (GRS); Stonehill College, Easton, Massachusetts; 26 June - 1 July 2022.

The conference has the theme "“Particulate Systems Across Scales: From Colloidal Science to Geophysical Flows”, and emphasizes the ubiquitous presence of granular matter at different scales and the broad application of granular physics in different research fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Particulate systems are ubiquitous in nature, ranging from colloids and emulsions to planetary bodies, from powders and aerosols to geophysical flows, from swarming bacteria and flocks of birds to large herds of animals.  As one of the most abundant materials, granular matter has been extensively studied in multiple disciplines of science and engineering. The underlying physics revealed in the study of granular matter have transformed our understanding of particulate systems across many scales. In particular, the physical principles governing the rich dynamics of granular matter have been greatly extended in recent years and broadly applied to diverse particulate systems ranging from colloidal suspensions, to biological fluids, and to planetary bodies. Within this exciting context, the tenth GRC on granular matter aimed to provide a unique platform for researchers in different fields to interact and discuss cutting-edge developments and novel applications of granular physics at different scales. Invited talks and posters from researchers in chemical, civil and mechanical engineering, physics, applied mathematics, earth and planetary sciences as well as engineers in industries were solicited to diversify the attendees of the meeting and stimulate open discussions on the new progress of granular research across scales.

Accompanying with the GRC, we also held the Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Granular Matter, which was a unique forum for graduate students, post-docs, and junior scientists to share and discuss ideas at the forefront of granular matter research as well as establish professional relationships in an informal environment. The seminar began with a scientific talk by keynote speaker Professor Ken Kamrin from MIT and concluded with Professor Karen Daniels from NC State sharing her insights on "Making a Life and a Career: strategic discussions you should be having with yourself, your loved ones, your adviser, and your future employer". Poster presentations provided students and postdocs with the opportunity to engage with colleagues to exchange ideas and share ongoing research. Oral presentations were selected from submitted abstracts.
